awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing the Linchpin of WAIS Collapse with Diatoms and IRD in Pleistocene and Late Pliocene Strata of the Resolution Drift, Amundsen Sea, Antarctica
awd_abstract_narration:
Part I, Non-technical Abstract 
Concerns that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) might be susceptible to releasing its ice as giant icebergs into the Southern Ocean due to a warming climate, raising global sea level, were first expressed more than 40 years ago. To best-assess this threat, scientists need to know whether such events occurred in the geologically recent past, during warm intervals of past glacial-interglacial cycles. Ocean drilling near the most vulnerable sector of the WAIS, in 2019, yielded seafloor geologic records demonstrating times when icebergs dropped large volumes of sands and pebbles, called ice-rafted detritus (IRD) in deep water of the Amundsen Sea.  Occurring together with IRD that was eroded from bedrock beneath the ice sheets, there are abundant microfossils of diatoms (algal plankton), which indicate high biological productivity in the open ocean. The new sediment cores provide a complete, uninterrupted record of a time of dramatic fluctuations of ice sheet extent that occurred over the last 3 million years.  Therefore, they provide the means to obtain clear answers to the question whether ice sheet collapse occurred in the past and offering clues to its potential future. This project will investigate sediment intervals where IRD coincides with evidence of high diatom production, to test whether these two criteria indicate rapid ice sheet collapse. Geochemical analysis of IRD pebbles will help trace the source of the icebergs to likely on-land sites. By analyzing conditions of high diatom and IRD accumulation in deep ocean sediment, where local coastal influences can be avoided, we will assess oceanographic and climatic conditions associated with past ice sheet collapse events.  Diatoms provide powerful evidence of temperature and ocean productivity changes in the past, that, when linked to time, can translate into rates of ice sheet drawdown. These results will provide critical data for designing, constraining and testing the next suite computer models that can determine the likelihood and timing of future ice sheet collapse in a warming world. The project will include training of undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds, and the public will be introduced to Antarctic science and engaged through several different outreach efforts.

Part 2, Technical Abstract

New drillcores from the Amundsen Sea, Antarctica (IODP Expedition 379) contain a continuous record of oceanographic changes and iceberg rafted debris (IRD) spanning the last 5 million years. This study aims to identify the signature of retreat/collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) in these continental margin, deep-sea sediments by quantitatively analyzing, in detail, diatom and IRD records across glacial-interglacial lithostratigraphic transitions to establish the timing and frequency of Late Pliocene and Pleistocene WAIS collapse events. The investigators will secure age constraints and diagnostic observations of marine paleoenvironmental conditions for selected interglacial intervals of cores from sites U1532 and U1533, using high resolution micropaleontology of diatom assemblages coupled with microstratigraphic analysis of IRD depositional events, while petrography, geochronology and thermochronology of iceberg rafted clasts will provide evidence of iceberg sources and pathways. Depositional paleotemperatures will be assessed via a new paleotemperature proxy based on quantitative assessment of morphologic changes in the dominant Southern Ocean diatom Fragilariopsis kerguelensis. Their results will contribute to parameterization of new ice sheet models that seek to reconstruct and forecast West Antarctic Ice Sheet behavior. This project will directly contribute to undergraduate education at an undergraduate-only college and at a public university that serves a demographic typified by first generation university students and underrepresented groups. Spanning geology, geochemistry, sedimentology, paleontology and paleoceanography, the proposed work will allow undergraduate students to develop diverse skills through hands-on research within a collaborative team that is dedicated to societally relevant research. The two graduate students will conduct original research and work alongside/mentor undergraduates, making for a well-rounded research experience that prepares them for success in future academic or employment sectors. The discoveries that come from this deep-sea record from West Antarctica will be communicated by students and investigators at national and international conferences and an array of public science outreach events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the present-day, there are many signs that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) might be nearing collapse, due to climate and ocean warming. One observation is the release of giant icebergs into the Southern Ocean, where the ‘bergs melt and contribute to sea level (SL) rise. For society to understand future SL projections, it is helpful to know whether such events occurred in the geologically recent past, during comparable warm periods. Ocean drilling near the most vulnerable sector of the WAIS, in 2019, yielded marine sediment cores that contain evidence of large volumes of sands and pebbles eroded from the Antarctic continent by glaciers. At their fronts, the glaciers broke into icebergs that rafted detritus (IRD) out to the deep water of the Amundsen Sea. During our shipboard work on the International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) expedition that recovered the drillcores, we observed that abundant microfossils of diatoms (algal plankton)occur together with the IRD – a sign of increased biological productivity in the open ocean during times when icebergs float through the area.

Our research used sediment from drill cores that contain a complete, uninterrupted record of the past 6 million years, a span that saw dramatic fluctuations of the ice sheet. We sought clear answers to the question whether ice sheet collapse occurred in the past (especially during the Pliocene through mid-Pleistocene Epochs, 5.3 to ~1.2 million years ago) and might yield clues to what is in store for the WAIS in the near future. We  analyzed the IRD pebbles and grains to obtain isotopic fingerprints to reveal where the icebergs’ ground-up rock and dust came from, on-land. We enlisted undergraduate and graduate student researchers, from diverse backgrounds, to join in on the research and develop professional skills that will aid the students’ future academic work and employment goals.

As far as our findings, one reassuring discovery is that a majority of clasts originated from the continental areas bordering the Amundsen Sea. This indicates that the changes in position of the ice sheet margin, and sites of glacial erosion, remained in the region near Amundsen Sea, without any deep retreat.  One more alarming finding is that four large clasts, and a few intervals of coarse siltstone, appear have been plucked by glaciers from fjords far inland and distant from Amundsen Sea.  The iceberg-rafted rocks match some sedimentary formations and distinctive granites that occur in the Ellsworth Mountains.  There had to be deep inland retreat of the WAIS edge into the Antarctic interior at that time, and on subsequent occasion (at  ~4.6 and 3.88 and  3.33 million years ago). When such warming and dramatic decrease in size of the West Antarctic ice sheet occurs, an continental seaway – like an ‘inner passage’-- develops through the center of Antarctica, and marine species such as squid and pelagic diatoms can extend their range right through and across Antarctica.

One further, special discovery comes from a bed of volcanic ash, or tephra, with a compositional makeup that is very unusual in Antarctica. The ash is iron-rich rhyolite, and a product of a big pyroclastic eruption with a large ash cloud that spread material as far as 1200 km (745 miles) across the sea.  The eruption may have come from a concealed caldera (eruptive center) in West Antarctica, active about 2.5 million years ago, just before a new Ice Age commenced.  It is possible that the ash and aerosols from volcanic eruptions promoted cooling of the regional climate, and aiding WAIS expansion.

Over the three years of the award, a total of 10 undergraduates were trained in use of fundamental and specialized instrumentation for work in petrology and isotopic analysis, while gaining abilities in data acquisition, reduction, and  communication of scientific findings in professional and public settings, sharing their discoveries about how ice rafted debris has unveiled past positions of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS), with implications for the ocean environment in the West Antarctic region and worldwide.

The significance of the NSF Linchpin project is that it provides information about icesheet interactions with the continental bedrock of Antarctica, constrained in time and tied to geographic locations. We obtained evidence of a responsive and dynamic WAIS that retreated and advanced repeatedly between ~6 and ~0.4 million years ago, before anthropogenic influences on global climate. The evidence foretells that contemporary climate warming is capable of causing West Antarctic ice sheet collapse in the future, and is available to climate scientists who are working to develop computer models that predict icesheet and ocean response.
